main event: On February 9, 1953, a civilian in Rosalia, Washington, approximately 20 miles south of Spokane, reported seeing a bright, round object in the sky moving rapidly at an altitude of 10,000 feet. The object appeared to be metallic, emitted no exhaust or trail, and disappeared after approximately 20 seconds. The observer noted that the object displayed rapid movements and accelerated away at high speed.
interesting points: The observed object was described as round and about 100-200 feet in diameter, with no observed propulsion system or aerodynamic features.
The object executed unusual maneuvers such as rapid acceleration, abrupt changes in direction, and hovering for about 20 minutes, according to the report.
The pilot's visual observations of the object were corroborated by radar contact, suggesting controlled flight with unusual and precise maneuvers.

A scheduled gas balloon release by the U.S. Weather Bureau was recorded, indicating that the released balloon would have been in the general vicinity of the sighting, consistent with the timing and location of the observed object.
It was concluded that the observed UFO was likely a weather balloon based on atmospheric conditions, wind patterns, and the estimated trajectory of the released balloon.
sighted object: a bright, round object moving rapidly in the sky
location: Rosalia, Washington (20 miles south of Spokane)
witnesses: civilian, pilot of a B-29 aircraft, Major Leo F. Korfatt of the 407th Bomb Squadron
photographs: yes, the report includes photographs and photographic charts
